SECTION: Section 11; Column 5; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1958 words

HEADLINE: Hi, My Name is Sam, and I'll be Your Broker

BYLINE: By ANNA BAHNEY

 BODY:
IN this city's central casting office, few stock characters are more set in their roles than the slick and savvy real estate agent and the starry-eyed starving artist waiting on tables.
 But increasingly, the two high-risk, high-gain professions are becoming a mutually beneficial hybrid. The real estate agent at the open house may have a familiar voice because he was selling shampoo on television the night before. The woman with the megawatt smile whose listings were found online might have several Web sites devoted to her and her character on a daytime soap opera. 
 Some might say that the merging of an actor and an agent is a kind of noxious New York nightmare. But it makes sense. Both are people who need to be able to work flexible schedules and to use maximum-minute cellphone plans to their advantage. 
 And the entry bar to real estate is not terribly high. A 45-hour training course followed by a state licensing test plus the strong residential market have made real estate today's version of waiting on tables or tending bar: it's a way not only to get by, but with a bit of luck to get ahead. 
 ''The grand metaphor of acting and real estate is that the more you get out there, the more you get work,'' said David Oppenheim, 29, whose stage name is David Austin.
 Mr. Oppenheim is at the beginning of his real estate career. He used to support his acting by waiting on tables and teaching swimming, but gave them up because he wanted a more professional job. In the month and a half that he's been a leasing agent with New York Apartments Unlimited, whose offices have a ''Glengarry Glen Ross'' movie poster on the door next to photographs of people in the office, he has rented three apartments and garnered a three-way commission split between a manager, his broker and himself on the first two (which paid him $200 and $700) and a 40/60 split on the last one (his 40 percent was $811).
 ''There is that possibility that you may not close a deal for a couple of weeks,'' he said. ''That can be pretty frightening. But this profession is not as saturated as being an actor.''
 Sometimes, the two worlds collide. Recently, he was looking very much the real estate agent, wearing a pinstriped charcoal suit with red tie and gleaming black shoes and leading a client, Liz Bradley, down West 49th Street to show her a $1,500-a-month, one-bedroom between 10th and 11th Avenues. 
 On the way Mr. Oppenheim ran into an acting colleague, Christopher Denham, in shorts and T-shirt, who is also in the movie ''Headspace,'' being filmed now in New York. Mr. Oppenheim told Mr. Denham about a costume-fitting in Los Angeles for his part as the ''aquatic creature'' in the science fiction thriller and bid him farewell with, ''If you ever need an apartment. . . .''
 Lucy Martin Gianino, a sales agent at Coldwell Banker Hunt Kennedy for eight years who has appeared in several Broadway productions in 35 years as an actress, said she came out of her first year in real estate with little more than a computer headache. ''Real estate is so like show business,'' Ms. Gianino said. ''You have to laugh. It's like, we already have a difficult profession, let's go out and find a more difficult profession.''
 More than 350 people take the state real estate exam at 9:30 a.m. every Tuesday at 123 William Street in New York. According to the New York Department of State, 13,609 people took the sales license test between Jan. 1 and June 25, up from 9,680 for the corresponding period in 2002. There are so many newcomers in the field that another test time has been added to accommodate the overflow.
 While their erratic schedules might seem like a hindrance, several real estate brokerage firms are finding that hiring actors is a good idea. Jimi Economou, the director of human resources at Citi Habitats, said his company welcomes entertainers. ''Real estate is something that can be taught,'' he said. ''Customer service is something for people who have a genuine ability to communicate and connect with someone. For actors and actresses it's innate.''
 Mr. Economou, in fact, places recruiting advertisements in the theater weekly Backstage and estimates that out of a sales force of 800 or so at Citi Habitats, 3 to 5 percent are also involved in the entertainment business. 
 At Dwelling Quest, Jay M. Heydt, the director of leasing, said three of his top leasing agents are actors, and a few others who split their time between showings and shows are doing so well with rentals that they are moving into sales.
 ''More and more, you're going to see actors getting away from bartending,'' Mr. Heydt, 26, said. In real estate, he said, ''you can make quadruple the income of tending bar all night. Are they going to serve somebody's steak or sign a lease and eat their own steak at the end of the day?''
 He'd rather have steak. With his deep, raspy voice that sounds like the actor Colin Quinn, Mr. Heydt has been doing commercial voice-over work since graduating from the University of Rhode Island in 2001. Though he was making enough to live on, he said, he wanted something on the side for financial insurance, and turned to real estate. 
 After becoming a top leasing producer at the East Village branch of Citi Habitats in 2002 and 2003, he was recruited by Dwelling Quest to head its leasing division, while still booming into living rooms with previews for the Discovery Channel's ''American Casino'' series and promos for HBO.
 The obvious draw of real estate for actors is the schedule, which is even more flexible than that of a temporary job or restaurant shift. The challenge, however, is managing it.
 At 2 p.m. on a Tuesday, Brian Keith Lewis, 34, an associate broker with Halstead Property, entered a cavernous loft space on West 15th Street, waiting to be called in for the first of his two auditions for the day. He had already completed walk-throughs on the Upper West Side and Upper East Side, attended two closings in Midtown and stopped at a Banana Republic for a new shirt (''Blue shows up better on camera,'' he said). He would have two apartment showings before heading home to update his Web site, field e-mail messages and return telephone calls. 
 ''You have to have a destination,'' Mr. Lewis said of the focus needed in both acting and selling. ''Uta Hagen taught me that. She'll roll in her grave if she hears me applying it to real estate, but it is the same thing: get to the deal.''
 Mr. Lewis, who sold the most listings for Halstead during the second quarter of 2004, carries a brown leather folder that is worn on the binding where he grips it. Inside is the relevant information for his eight properties in contract, two coming to market, four exclusives and extra head shots of himself.
 ''You don't want to look like a wannabe,'' Mr. Lewis said. ''You show that you're doing both and you're successful and that's who you are.'' 
 Among his clients are Marc and Sabrina Paradis, who are hiring him for the third time this fall because he successfully sold a tricky basement apartment they had owned. They did not know that he was an actor until their second deal when Mrs. Paradis went to see ''A Beautiful Mind'' and saw a close-up of a familiar face. (He played one of the Princeton professors at a ''pen ceremony.'')
 ''Oh my god! That's my Realtor!'' Mrs. Paradis recalled yelling during the movie at a Union Square theater.
 ''I was completely impressed because I had no idea,'' said Mrs. Paradis, who works in the financial department at Pfizer. ''He made it invisible to us, as though this was his primary job.''
 After moving to New York to be an actor in 1991, Mr. Lewis had a successful run at commercial work, (''I was the Head and Shoulders guy in the 90's,'' he said) and didn't get into real estate until 1999 (unless a part in a reading opposite Joan Rivers in a play called ''Killing Real Estate Women'' counts). Mr. Lewis said it was turning 30 that made him reconsider his options as an actor. 
 ''I'm not 'La Boheme'; I'm not 'Rent.' '' Mr. Lewis said. ''I saw that show and I was like, 'Pay your damn rent, you're a bunch of suburban kids acting like bohemians.' ''
 Unlike many actors, Mr. Lewis no longer has to pay rent. Last year, he bought a two-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side. 
 The money is there to be made, if actors are willing and able. Daren Hornig, president and chief executive of Dwelling Quest, said that all of the actors at his real estate firm, ''are making six digits or a lot more.''
 This explains why many get into the profession to get by and never get out. Stefani Pace, 25, a leasing agent with Dwelling Quest who is also a model, said she hardly has time to book gigs now. ''I hate to go away,'' she said, ''because you lose the knowledge of the inventory.''
 Priorities tipped the other way for Jerry Richardson, 30, who was working as a leasing agent when he went on a vacation to Montana and decided when he returned he would focus on acting because that was why he had come to New York and he did not like fitting it around his work schedule. But he was unable to find enough acting jobs to live on, he said, and so ''that lasted a short time.'' He's now a leasing agent at Dwelling Quest.
 For Victoria Rong, 26, an associate broker for Citi Habitats and a film actress, keeping a foot in movies by continuing to audition opens doors in real estate. Her film social circle keeps her in touch with people looking for high-end real estate.
 ''As an actress, maybe they cannot provide me with a movie job,'' Ms. Rong said. But when they learn she does residential sales, ''they say, 'But I am looking for a co-op.' ''
 Ms. Rong muses that if she continues to excel at selling real estate, she could stop auditioning and finance her own film. She said on some multimillion dollar properties, she makes $120,000. ''Something like this you could never dream of in other jobs.''
 ''It was empowering when I started real estate,'' said David Neiman, a leasing agent at Dwelling Quest. While writing and acting in his own plays, he had been fired from eight restaurant jobs in a year and a half because of scheduling conflicts. When he started leasing, he said, he wasn't making any money, but ''I was just so excited to find a job I could function in.''
 Now he's almost afraid to mention real estate to some of his theater colleagues for fear of future competition.
 Kathy Schrier, managing director of the Actors' Work Program, a division of the Actors' Fund of America, helps people in the industry navigate career transitions and find meaningful sideline work. 
 ''By nature people in the arts have a lot of talents that work for real estate,'' Ms. Schrier said. ''They know New York. They've lived here and worked here. The uncertainty in real estate is common to the entertainment industry. If you did a Myers-Briggs and looked at risk taking -- risk taking is big,'' she said, referring to the personality test.
 But she cautioned it is not for everyone. ''Real estate isn't right for someone who's going to be on the road for six months because you'd lose all your clients.'' Ms. Schrier said.
 For all actor-agents the time comes when they have to be in two places at once and are faced with a tough decision. For Mrs. Gianino it was in early 2002. She was the agent enlisted by former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Judith Nathan to find them an Upper East Side apartment while simultaneously rehearsing ''The Play About the Baby'' by Edward Albee. In Philadelphia. 
 After a rehearsal Mr. Albee made a surprise appearance to speak to the cast -- but Mrs. Gianino had an appointment with Mr. Giuliani and Ms. Nathan.
 ''Rudy and Judy and the Secret Service were going to be waiting for me,'' Mrs. Gianino recalled. ''I had to say to Mr. Albee, 'Excuse me, but I have to go.' ''

SECTION: Section 13; Column 1; Television; CRITIC'S CHOICE; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 585 words

BYLINE: By Anita Gates

 BODY:
STEPHEN GLASS (Hayden Christensen, a k a the young Anakin Skywalker) tells his editor at The New Republic that he feels awful because he's made a ''huge error'' in an article. The young Republicans weren't drinking booze from a hotel mini-bar; it actually came from a rented fridge. But in SHATTERED GLASS (2003), that's the least of young Stephen's sins. He's the nicest guy in the world, it seems, but he, uh, makes up half of his articles. And he gets caught. Peter Sarsgaard plays the editor who digs out the truth. Billy Ray wrote, directed and proved that backstage journalism can make entertaining moral drama and fact-checking can be fun-- Friday at 5 p.m. on Cinemax. 
 There's good news and bad for Ann Darrow (Fay Wray, who died last month at 96) in the sci-fi classic of classics KING KONG (1933). Ann, an unemployed New York actress, has reached the point of stealing food when she's spotted by a filmmaker (Robert Armstrong) and hired for his mysterious new project. He buys her a new wardrobe, and they set sail on a ship bound for an East Indies island where the natives live in fear of something called Kong. You know the rest. Kong turns out to be a big ape, falls in love with Ann at first sight, carries her away (the ship's first mate, played by Bruce Cabot, saves her), is captured and exhibited on Broadway, breaks his chains and makes movie history by carrying Ann up the Empire State Building. 
 Merian C. Cooper and Ernest B. Schoedsack directed -- Friday at 10:15 p.m. on TCM. 
 Dr. David Hurst (Campbell Scott) seems to have an enviable life. David, the protagonist of Alan Rudolph's scarily realistic domestic comedy THE SECRET LIVES OF DENTISTS (2002), is married to and shares his practice with a beautiful dentist (Hope Davis) who also sings opera. They have a lovely home, a country house and three adorable little daughters, but David spends the film trapped in tortured fantasy after he sees his wife kissing another man. Denis Leary plays the world's most annoying patient (finally, a role that lets Mr. Leary put his innate obnoxiousness to full use) -- Thursday at 9 p.m. and Saturday at 6:15 p.m. on Showtime. 
 Mr. Rudolph looks at another tortured soul in MRS. PARKER AND THE VICIOUS CIRCLE (1994), about Dorothy Parker (Jennifer Jason Leigh), cynical theater critic, poet, screenwriter and queen of the Algonquin Round Table. This is bleak stuff, but Ms. Leigh captures the essence of witty, sophisticated loneliness. (''You don't want to become the town drunk, Eddie,'' she tells her first husband. ''Not in Manhattan.'') And Campbell Scott (apparently a Rudolph favorite) is exceptional as the humorist Robert Benchley, Parker's platonic love. There's a huge ensemble cast, and those who look hard will see Gwyneth Paltrow in a small role as a starlet, Paula Hunt -- Sunday at 10 p.m. and Sunday/Early Monday at 3:55 a.m. on IFC. 
 It's a love story and a tale of personal determination and courage. In Taylor Hackford's absorbing drama AN OFFICER AND A GENTLEMAN (1982), Richard Gere stars as Zack Mayo, a poor kid intent on becoming a Navy flier, no matter how tough the training, because he has nowhere else to go. Debra Winger plays a local girl doomed to a drab lifelong factory job unless someone takes her away from all this. The most memorable supporting performance is Louis Gossett Jr.'s Oscar-winning one as Zack's intense drill sergeant, who tells him he'll never make it and calls him Mayo-naisse -- Friday at 7:30 and 11 p.m. and Saturday at 3:30 p.m. on WE.

SECTION: Section 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk; The Nation: Swing-State Distortions; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 1130 words

HEADLINE: A Presidential Campaign Tinged With Rust

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

 BODY:
THE names must seem like mantras for schedulers on the Bush and Kerry campaigns: Ohio, West Virginia, Pennsylvania, Michigan, Wisconsin. Those great swing states of the aging industrial heartland have become the tape loop of the 2004 campaign, linked by their Rust Belt tribulations and stodgy disavowal of permanent Red or Blue status. Having fallen behind economically, they have surged to the forefront politically this year on the wings of their industrial frailty.
 But if the candidates or their running mates seem to be in one of those states every other day -- which, in fact, they are, if not every day -- what has the focus on the Rust Belt meant for the rest of the union? Has the national debate been distorted by one region? 
 Politicians and analysts from the Midwest insist that it has not. States like Ohio and Michigan are perfect microcosms of the nation, they argue, with liberal cities and conservative Bible belts, diverse immigrant communities alongside all-white suburbs, clean high-tech industries replacing belching smokestacks. 
 ''You could save a lot of money if we just held the presidential election in Ohio,'' joked John Green, director of the Bliss Institute of Applied Politics at the University of Akron. ''Utah is not getting the attention that Ohio is, but there are parts of Ohio that are as conservative as Utah. And there are parts that are as liberal as New York. The very competitive states do represent a diversity of views, and that's one reason they are so competitive.''
 But talk to political analysts in Utah, New York or California, and you are likely to get a very different perspective. The electoral map has slanted the debate this year, they contend, leaving issues ignored or overplayed. 
 ''States like California and New York are essentially left out of the election, which means our interests don't get as much discussion,'' said Bruce Cain, the director of the Institute of Governmental Studies at the University of California, Berkeley.
 Much attention has been paid, for instance, to the needs of old-line manufacturers that have been pummeled by foreign competition, from steel to bearings. Some of those industries have been pressing for trade barriers, while their unions demand pension protections and restrictions on outsourcing. 
 In West Virginia last week, President Bush made a point of reminding steel-producing states of his efforts to protect them, by imposing tariffs on imported steel for nearly two years ending in December 2003. But a hearty debate on industrial modernization and free trade might be more pertinent to the nation as a whole, many economists say. 
 ''Anyone campaigning in that part of the world is going to be torn between two worlds,'' said Richard Feinberg, an economist at the University of California at San Diego and a former Clinton administration official. ''For a national audience, the candidates talk about economic modernism, global mobility and open markets. But in that part of the world, there is a temptation to appeal to the romanticism of the industrial Midwest, with its memories of a faded golden era when they had a virtual global monopoly.''
 Many analysts also say the Democrats have tiptoed around several hot-button issues, including the environment, gun control and gay rights, that are important to core Democrats but do not play well with conservative swing voters in the Midwest.
 ''The environment in these industrial states is always a problem,'' said G. Terry Madonna, a pollster and professor of public affairs at Franklin & Marshall College in Lancaster, Pa. ''Strong environmental changes means losing jobs to many people here.''
 No surprise, then, that President Bush used a trip to Michigan just before the Republican convention to praise the auto industry for making ''the cleanest cars and trucks in history'' and accuse Senator John Kerry of proposing ''arbitrary, unfair fuel standards that could cost Michigan thousands of jobs.''
 Certainly independent advocacy groups would spend millions of dollars to spotlight those issues in the swing states, even if the candidates did not. But that has not lessened the frustration of people in other regions who would like to hear a more full-throated debate between the candidates. 
 ''On certain social issues, there are huge differences between California swing voters and Rust Belt swing voters,'' Professor Cain said. ''And there is a frustration here that the Democrats can't bring up those issues because of that disagreement.''
 There is a more pertinent question for the Rust Belt itself: Will the lavish attention it is getting translate into lasting benefits once the courtship is over? Probably not, experts say. 
 Years ago, when political machines could deliver cities and even states, presidents were more likely to reward them with contracts, patronage and post offices, said John Petrocik, chairman of the political science department at the University of Missouri. But with the demise of political machines, the shrinkage of labor unions and the rise of independent 527 groups, there have been fewer spoils of victory, he said.
 ''My impression is that there is relatively little tangible benefit that a state gets by virtue of being a target state,'' he said. ''Today, there is much more of an appeal directly to the voter, and that doesn't lead to as much of a payout.''
 There is, of course, nothing new about the industrial Midwest being a presidential battleground. That is a result, analysts say, of the region's demographic diversity and political independence, traits that have made it harder to categorize than the reliably Republican Mountain States or the Democratic Northeast.
 The region's large number of blue-collar social conservatives are emblematic of that independence. Once die-hard New Deal Democrats, they drifted away from the national party over civil rights, urban crime, affirmative action, gun control, abortion and national defense. In 1972, disgust with Vietnam protesters drove many into the arms of Richard Nixon. In 1980, they became the Reagan Democrats. 
 But they have been known to return to the Democratic fold during economic downturns, as happened with Bill Clinton's victory in 1992. Mr. Kerry's fortunes depend on that happening again, analysts say, but his campaign has been thrown off-message lately by attacks on his Vietnam War record. If Mr. Bush can keep the debate focused on terrorism, national security and the war in Iraq -- and away from the Rust Belt's woes -- the region is more likely to tilt Republican, analysts say. 
 ''People here are waiting for someone to talk to them about health care and jobs,'' said Ed Sarpolus, vice president of EPIC/MRA, a Michigan consulting firm. ''And if Kerry and Edwards don't talk to them, they won't vote for change.''

HEADLINE: Chelsea Building Swaps Muses, From Photography to Dance

BYLINE: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

 BODY:
A DECIDEDLY blurry real estate picture is finally coming into focus for the photographer Annie Leibovitz.
 Ms. Leibovitz, best known for her photos of celebrities in the magazine Vanity Fair, has sold her Chelsea studio and an adjoining building for $11.37 million to a fledgling dance and theater company sponsored by an heir to the Wal-Mart fortune. 
 At the same time, she has decided to forge ahead with the stalled renovation of a pair of Greenwich Village town houses, which turned famously disastrous two years ago when a damaged wall adjoining a neighboring building threatened to collapse. 
 Ms. Leibovitz, who currently lives in a penthouse in London Terrace in Chelsea, said she hoped to have structural problems with the town houses fixed by the end of the month, clearing the way for her to move forward with the renovation. 
 The sale last month of her Chelsea studio and office, she said, is a turning point that will finally make her move to Greenwich Village possible. 
 Ms. Leibovitz bought the Chelsea buildings at 537-547 West 26th Street -- twin one-story garages -- in August 1999. She declined to discuss the purchase price, but calculations based on city tax records indicate that the buildings cost $2.1 million.
 She converted one of them into a studio and left the other vacant.
 It became clear, however, that she didn't need so much space (the two buildings total nearly 14,000 square feet) and earlier this year, she decided to put them up for sale. She listed the property with Alf Naman, an independent broker, at an initial asking price of $13 million. It was later dropped to $11.75 million.
 Mr. Naman said Ms. Leibovitz received offers to split the property but preferred a buyer who would use both buildings. ''Annie really felt the buildings had a lot of integrity as a pair,'' he said.
 In the meantime, Lucy J. Ballard, the executive and artistic director of the newly established Cedar Lake Ensemble, had spent months fruitlessly searching for a theater the company could call home.
 In late July, Ms. Ballard's broker, Ian Keate of the Corcoran Group, took her to see the twin garages, with their voluminous, column-free interiors. 
 ''I was so elated,'' Ms. Ballard said. ''As soon as I walked in, bingo, it was absolutely the right place.'
 Ms. Ballard called Nancy Walton Laurie, the owner of the Cedar Lake company. The two moved quickly, agreeing by the middle of August to buy the property for $11.37 million. On Aug. 27 Ms. Laurie closed the deal with a cash payment. 
 She is the daughter of James L. Walton, who helped his brother Sam start the Wal-Mart Stores chain. Ms. Laurie, who lives in Columbia, Mo., was ranked at No. 61 last year on the Forbes magazine list of the richest Americans, with a fortune estimated at $2.9 billion.
 Two years ago, she persuaded Ms. Ballard to join her in starting Cedar Lake. 
 Today, the company consists of a ballet ensemble with 22 dancers and some 15 performances under its belt, as well as a nascent theatrical group that has yet to put on a production. 
 Ms. Ballard hopes to raise the curtain on the dance ensemble's first show in the new space next March. She has hired the architect Paul Byard of Platt Byard Dovell White, to create a theater with about 250 seats in the property's eastern half. That will involve raising the roof some 30 feet to accommodate technical needs. They plan to preserve the peaked facade of the garages, which were built in about 1915. The western structure will house offices and rehearsal studios. Ms. Ballard declined to say how much the renovation will cost. 
 As for Ms. Leibovitz, she also faces a complex renovation, but one with a more complicated history. 
 She bought the two 1830's town houses at 755 and 757 Greenwich Street in April 2002, for $4.15 million. The buildings had been carved up into rooming houses long before, and she began a renovation project intended to turn one building into a residence and the other into a combination office and nanny's apartment.
 But in October 2002, work to excavate the basement of 755 Greenwich Street undermined a party wall with the building at 311 West 11th Street. The wall shifted (Ms. Leibovitz says it dropped four inches) and forced the evacuation of the family living next door. 
 The house's owner sued Ms. Leibovitz, charging her with trying to pressure him to sell his home at a below-market price. Local preservationists accused her of carrying out a reckless renovation that threatened to destroy the historical value of the homes in the landmark neighborhood. They even picketed her town houses.
 Finally, after a rancorous year of charges and countercharges, in which Ms. Leibovitz was fined $1,000 for excavating her basement without a permit and was forced to shore up the damaged structures with hefty steel buttresses, she settled with her neighbor and agreed to buy his house for $1.87 million. (He had bought it for $712,500 in 1995). 
 On the advice of her lawyers, Ms. Leibovitz then put all three town houses on the market, through Mr. Naman, at a combined asking price of $7 million. Yet, despite all the difficulty, she had become attached to them, and eventually decided to push ahead with the work. 
 ''I've always had a dream about living in the West Village,'' she said.
 ''I went out and looked at 12 other buildings, and I came back to these buildings and I said, 'I like this.' '' She added, ''I still believe in them.''
 She dismissed any accusations that she had intentionally triggered the structural damage as a way of forcing out her neighbor. She said that once the renovation was done, she would either sell the house she bought from him or keep it as a rental property. 
 Of the construction mishap, she said: ''It's just the kind of thing that happens sometimes when you renovate old buildings. I have nothing but respect for the neighborhood. I was trying to do a very nice renovation that was totally by the boards. The landmarks people were totally overjoyed with our plans. It was just bad luck that this thing happened.''
 Ultimately, she said, the work on the town houses will prove her good intentions. 
 ''Once I move in there, I hope to get to know people and get along with people,'' she said. ''I'm a staunch preservationist myself.''

Chelsea Condo Draws Celebrities
 The actress Kate Winslet and her husband, the director Sam Mendes, paid $4.9 million in July for a duplex penthouse condominium in a converted Chelsea building that is becoming a de facto celebrity boarding house.
 The 12-unit building, tucked inconspicuously among the neighborhood's art galleries and fashion boutiques, is also home to Martie Maguire of the Dixie Chicks, who bought an apartment there in December 2002 for $2.15 million. 
 The Icelandic pop star Bjork also owns an apartment in the building, although a broker familiar with the property said she does not live there. 
 The actor Alan Cumming owned an apartment in the building until he sold it for $2.75 million in late July, according to city records. (He bought it 16 months earlier for $1.92 million, records show.) Mr. Cumming came to prominence in the United States with his star turn in the Broadway revival of ''Cabaret,'' which was directed by Mr. Mendes.
 Simon Halls, a publicist for Ms. Winslet and Mr. Mendes, said the British-born power couple plan to use the three-bedroom apartment with a terrace as their home during stays in New York. Their primary residence is a stone house in a village in the Cotswold area in the south of England.

More Inventory Expected In Quieter Luxury Market
 Has the overheated real estate market started to cool? 
 Kirk Henckels, the director of Stribling Private Brokerage, writes in a midyear report on luxury residential sales that New York is experiencing ''a market in transition, a market past its peak.''
 In an analysis of sales of Manhattan co-ops and town houses for more than $4 million, Mr. Henckels concluded the booming market that began in mid- to late 2003 and surged through the first few months of this year was ''the hottest market in New York's luxury residential real estate history.'' 
 By the end of April, however, the market started to show ''erratic behavior,'' a new ''quietness'' and a less-frenzied pace. 
 But that doesn't mean prices will plummet. ''The last half of 2004 should be a more stable and balanced market than the hysteria of the first half,'' he said. He predicts that prices will level off and inventory will rise.
 ''We really follow consumer confidence and the economy,'' he said in an interview. ''We don't know where this economy is going right now.'' 
 The Stribling report says there were 73 co-op apartments sold for $4 million and above in the first six months of this year, compared with 41 in the same period last year and 51 in the first six months of 2002. The numbers are for completed sales. 
 The report also logs 48 town house sales from January through June, compared with 20 in the first six months of 2003 and 24 in the first half of 2002.

HEADLINE: Does a Tiger Lurk in the Middle of a Fearful Symmetry?

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

DATELINE: CHORWON, South Korea 

 BODY:
From atop an observatory hard on the southern limit of the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea, Lim Sun Nam peered through binoculars at the cold-war spectacle below. He paid no attention to the barbed wire fences, the guard posts with rifle-toting soldiers, or the propaganda billboards on the northern side exclaiming ''Against America'' and ''Prosperity of the People.''
 No, Mr. Lim took in the verdant hills undulating across the 2.5-mile-wide strip of land and the river snaking through it here in one of the DMZ's most scenic points. His eyes searched for the deer, wild pigs and pheasants living in the zone as well as the elusive animal whose existence here he has spent the last seven years trying to prove: the tiger.
 Although Mr. Lim may or may not find the tiger, environmentalists have recognized this area -- one of the most enduring symbols of the cold war and one of the most fortified and heavily mined stretches on earth -- as the Korean peninsula's, and possibly East Asia's, most important wildlife refuge. They have been pressing to preserve it but are feeling a special urgency now because of the growing reconciliation between the North and the South. 
 The environmentalists fear that a South Korea that puts economic development first and a North Korea that has no environmental movement could together lead to the zone's rapid destruction as a refuge.
 This natural barrier traverses wetlands, rice paddies, prairies, hills, forests and mountains for more than 150 miles. Enclosed by barbed wire and left virtually untouched since it was created in 1953, the zone has become a haven for animals, birds and plants that are seldom seen elsewhere on the peninsula. 
 Migratory birds, including the endangered black-faced spoonbill and the white-naped and red-crowned cranes, fly in and out, oblivious to land barriers. Rare animals like the Asiatic black bear, the Eurasian lynx, goral antelopes -- and maybe even the tiger -- make this area their year-round home.
 But these days, thousands of South Koreans pass every week through an eastern corridor to a resort in North Korea; on the western side, a new highway and a railroad linking the two sides have been built. 
 ''The DMZ is the last major vestige of Korea's natural heritage,'' said Kim Ke Chung, a professor at the Center for BioDiversity Research at Penn State and chairman of the DMZ Forum, an organization based in the United States that is dedicated to preserving the zone. ''It's probably the only good thing to come out of the Korean War and cold war. So we have to preserve this as a nature reserve.''
 The DMZ Forum recently held a conference in Seoul to gather support for designating the zone a Unesco World Heritage Site, a classification that would curb all development. William B. Shore, secretary of the forum and a former fellow at the Regional Plan Association of New York, said the zone should become a center for eco-tourism as an alternative to turning it into a weekend getaway for residents of Seoul.
 ''People are now willing to pay large sums to see wild animals in the proper setting,'' Mr. Shore said. ''Eco-tourism would protect the DMZ from becoming the Hamptons of South Korea.''
 South Korea and North Korea, however, would have to ask for World Heritage status. North Korea has shown no interest in the issue, said Sohn Hak Kyu, governor of Kyonggi Province, which abuts the zone and was host for the conference. A unified peninsula would focus on North Korea's economic development, and prewar landowners could lay claim to pieces of the zone, Mr. Sohn said.
 ''There will be strong resistance from North and South Korea to such a designation,'' he said.
 Although South Korea has not expressed support for the designation, it has begun recognizing the zone's natural legacy. Early this year, South Korea's National Tourism Organization proposed creating an eco-tourism center here in Chorwon, an area about 60 miles northeast of Seoul and famous for its bird-watching. Tourists would be permitted just south of the zone in a so-called civilian-controlled area, a heavily militarized zone that includes cordoned-off minefields and roads flanked by antitank defenses. 
 South Korea built ecologically friendly safeguards into the new road and railroads, with so-called eco-bridges and eco-tunnels to allow animals to cross safely over or under the roads. North Korea, which initially suspected that the crossings served some military purpose, has not shown any interest in building similar safeguards into its portions of the roads, Mr. Sohn said.
 For some South Koreans, the zone represents something deeper than a natural paradise. It is the only tract of land that has remained intact from before Korea was divided. As a last refuge for species no longer seen elsewhere, but off limits to all but a few Koreans, it represents a spiritual loss to some.
 The tiger symbolizes that loss more than any other animal. Tigers once populated the peninsula and, in traditional culture, were considered holy animals embodying a mountain deity. The tiger's importance in Korean culture was underscored during the 1988 Seoul Olympics, when it was chosen as South Korea's mascot. The last tigers were believed to have been hunted down by Japanese colonial rulers, which adds to the animal's symbolic importance.
 Mr. Lim, who has been searching for the tiger for seven years but has yet to see one, described his quest in a recent visit here.
 ''I am searching not only for the tiger, but the spirit and soul of Korea,'' he said. ''Because the DMZ is not polluted -- it's preserved -- the Korean spirit is still alive there.''
 Mr. Lim, 48, a former television cameraman and documentary filmmaker, has found and videotaped what appeared to be tiger footprints inside the restricted civilian-controlled zone just south of the DMZ. Since doing research on the tiger in the late 1990's, Mr. Lim has devoted his life to his quest. Children call him Tiger Man. He quit his job in 2001 and sold his house. He and his family moved in with his older brother, who supports him but has also pressed him to get a new job. 
 Some wildlife experts in South Korea believe that the tiger is extinct and that footprints seen by Mr. Lim belong to wild dogs. Mr. Lim waves away such criticism, saying, ''You won't find tiger footprints on college campuses.''
 He went to Siberia to learn how to track tigers and has searched for them across stretches south of the zone, typically combing mountains for footprints during the winter. His goal is to film one. But the futility of the last seven years has sometimes taken its toll, plunging Mr. Lim into bouts of uncertainty that were alleviated only by outside interest in his efforts.
 ''One time I was in despair and told the tiger, 'I don't care if you become extinct,''' Mr. Lim said, recalling a fruitless search over several days in the mountain snow. ''I said, 'If you are a spiritual animal, you should help me.' I decided to give up my search for the tiger. But when I started going down the mountain, I got a call on my mobile phone. It was an invitation to speak at a special conference on the tiger.''

HEADLINE: Stephanie Hill, Benjamin Wilchfort

 BODY:
Stephanie Frederica Hill, the daughter of Lyn Stiefel Hill and Forbes I. Hill of Brooklyn, is to be married in Manhattan today to Benjamin Simon Wilchfort, the son of Blanka and Dr. David Wilchfort of Munich. Rabbi Gerald I. Weider is to officiate at the Rainbow Room. 
 The bride, 28, works in Manhattan as the director of fund-raising for the New York area for CARE, the international relief organization. She graduated from the State University at Binghamton, N.Y., and received a master's in international economic policy from Columbia. Her father retired as a professor of communication at Queens College in Flushing. Her mother is the vice president for planning, public affairs and fund-raising at New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn.
 Mr. Wilchfort, 35, is a Web site designer, an interactive media producer and a producer of industrial videos and documentary films in Manhattan. He was a researcher for the documentary ''September Songs: The Music of Kurt Weill,'' and is now producing , ''The Last Generation: German Jews in New York,''a documentary about the prewar period. He graduated with honors from York University in Toronto. His mother, a psychotherapist, and his father, a psychiatrist, practice together in Munich. His mother is also a sculptor whose work is on exhibit in Kaiserslautern, Germany.
 The couple met in 2000 at a service at Congregation Habonim, a West Side synagogue founded in 1939 for Jewish refugees from Germany. He was doing research for ''The Last Generation,'' and she was there as the guest of a woman she had met through work and because her grandparents had been longtime members.
 She remembers that he was surrounded by elderly women who were eager to have their stories told on television and that one of them seized her and marched her up for an introduction. ''It could be because we were the only two people who were under 75,'' Ms. Hill said.
 He was ''very impressed with her looks,'' he said.
 They spoke briefly, and he asked for her card on the pretext of wanting to learn more about her family's German Jewish history. But he says now that his real motive was not in the least documentary.
 ''I really wanted to ask her out,'' Mr. Wilchfort said, ''but I thought, somehow, a synagogue was a respectable place where you don't pick up girls.''

HEADLINE: A Phone Venture: Calling All Prisoners

BYLINE: By Ian Urbina. 
This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com

 BODY:
BRIAN PRINS's motto is this: One man's monopoly is another man's opportunity. After being released from prison in May 2002, the first thing he did was to make a business of pulling customers from under MCI's exclusive control of New York States prison phone system.
 Last year, his company, Outside Connection, based in Bellmore, N.Y., made nearly $2 million. It is among a handful of new ''remote-call forwarding'' services around the country that provide people with a way around the monopolies that many states grant to large phone companies for control over collect calls coming from inside state prisons. 
 These services provide the families of inmates with a phone number that is local to where their relative is in prison. When the inmate dials the number, the call is redirected to the family's home number and expensive long-distance charges are avoided. In New York, that means $5.80 for a half-hour call using Mr. Prins's service rather than the $8.10 charged by MCI.
 ''I know from first-hand experience what a huge difference these savings can make,'' Mr. Prins said.
 After serving five years in Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora, N.Y., on charges of aggravated assault and criminal possession of stolen-car parts, Mr. Prins said he returned home to find his family thousands of dollars in debt. ''They had been paying close to $1,000 a month to receive my calls,'' he said.
 For every one of the 67,000 or so inmates in New York prisons, Mr. Prins said, there is a mother, son or a sister who wants to keep in touch. Few of these families can afford to travel to the prison and even fewer can afford the expensive phone rates, he said.
 But prison officials oppose remote-call forwarding services, claiming that these services limit the ability for authorities to monitor calls and ensure that inmates are not using the phones to make drug deals or threats. State officials are equally dismayed because these services drain part of the nearly 60 percent in commission that New York makes on prison collect calls. In 2003, New York made more than $20 million from prison calls.
 Mr. Prins pointed out that Outside Connection is a licensed telecommunications company and that remote-call forwarding is legal. He said his company provided the same security checks that MCI offered, including the recording of all conversations and lists of approved numbers and addresses where inmate calls can be directed. ''We explained our security capabilities but the state still rejects anyone other than MCI entering this market,'' he said. 
 Last year, prison officials and the phone company stepped up their opposition to remote call forwarding services.
 In July, correctional authorities told inmates that using the services was strictly forbidden, and many inmates reported being threatened with solitary confinement for breaking the rules. But Mr. Prins said the threats did not put a dent in his business. Most inmates are willing to take their chances breaking the rules, he said, if it means saving money for families who are struggling in their absence.
 In late August of last year, MCI changed its billing plan, imposing a flat 16-cents-perminute rate for all local and long-distance calls in state. ''This tactic hit us really hard,'' said Mr. Prins, explaining that the rate change undercut the amount of savings he could offer in-state customers. Within three months his company lost nearly a million dollars in sales and he had to lay off five of his six employees.
 So Mr. Prins turned to greener pastures.
 First, he began plumbing ''blocked lists'' that include people MCI has cut from being able to receive calls from inmates. Most of the people on these lists, Mr. Prins explained, are there because they got their phone service through AT&T, a cable company, or an internet provider, none of which have billing agreements with MCI and therefore are automatically prevented from receiving calls from New York inmates. 
 Mr. Prins also began looking out of state for customers. MCI's new billing plan had flattened prices for in-state calls, but it did not drop out-of-state rates.
 Revenue has since rebounded and Mr. Prins said he has been able to rehire most of his original employees. Nevertheless, he remains cautious about the future.
 ''It's only a matter of time before the state and MCI try to find ways to close down these new areas of competition,'' Mr. Prins said. But the bottom line is that I'll just move to another corner of the monopoly.''

Game, Set and Match For Acclaim Entertainment
 Edward Slezak, a vice president and the general counsel of Acclaim Entertainment (Nasdaq: AKLM.PK), the troubled Glen Cove video game publisher, refused Wednesday to deny a report in Newsday that the company had ceased operations. 
 Mr. Slezak said he would not reply to questions concerning the company.
 Michael Davidson, the executive director of the Glen Cove Chamber of Commerce, said he stopped by Acclaim's building on Wednesday afternoon and found the front door locked. Only a few cars were in the parking lot, he added.
 On Tuesday, the company reported a $25.4 million loss for the quarter that ended March 31. Revenues dropped below $29 million for the quarter, the company said, a decline of about 26 percent from the previous quarter when revenues totaled $39.3 million.
 Newsday reported on Tuesday that the company had dismissed most of its employees and had ceased operations. Throughout the summer, the company struggled to arrange loans that would forestall a bankruptcy filing. Last month, it told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had failed to do so. 
 Acclaim said in a regulatory filing in March that it had 585 employees in Glen Cove; Austin, Tex.; and Manchester, England.

Layoffs for GreenPoint Workers
 The North Fork Bancorp (NYSE: NFB) of Melville said Wednesday it would lay off about 300 employees of the GreenPoint Financial Corporation, whose assets it bought earlier this year.
 Most of the workers who will lose their jobs are back-office employees, said John A. Kanas, North Fork's chairman. Mr. Kanas said the bank had not yet decided on branch closings. GreenPoint has about 1,500 employees, most of them in New York City and Nassau County, Mr. Kanas said.

Incentives for Paint Company
 The Nassau County Industrial Development Authority said last week that it planned to offer an economic incentive package to the Paint Applicator Corporation of America, a paint wholesaler in Maspeth, Queens. 
 The company has signed a contract to buy the Bernstein Display's 81,000-square-foot building in the Port Washington Industrial Park. Paint Applicator has about 100 employees, the Nassau agency said. Terms of the incentive package have not yet been determined. Compiled by Warren Strugatch

HEADLINE: Trying to Clean House at the Federation of Labor

BYLINE: By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
THIS weekend, at the parades and barbecues, at the rallies and the picnics that local unions will hold for members and their families, one familiar face will be missing: Jack Caffey's.
 A spending scandal now playing out at the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Long Island council, the regional umbrella group, has resulted in the suspension of Mr. Caffey, the local's president and one of the region's most powerful labor leaders. The council, known as the Long Island Federation of Labor, is in receivership, and the union's national leadership is weighing Mr. Caffey's future.
 Mr. Caffey, a former seafarers' union official, was suspended in June without pay by the union, after the local's trustees reported evidence that as much as $200,000 had been misspent in a training program administered by the council's headquarters in Farmingdale. 
 The union's national representatives, who are currently running the local's day-to-day operations, sought to play down any long-lasting damage to organized labor's image on Long Island that might result from the scandal. Others, including organizers, allies and adversaries, were less sanguine.
 ''It's a step backwards'' for organized labor on Long Island, said Judy Pannullo, who through much of the last decade was the executive director of the Long Island Progressive Coalition, an organization that rallied civic and religious groups to support organized labor. 
 Last month, Jose Alvarez, a national A.F.L.-C.I.O. trustee and the acting administrator of the council, handed over the results of an independent audit to the Suffolk County district attorney, along with files related to the questionable expenditures. The report concluded that a training program employee who had reported to Mr. Caffey had used a union credit card for multiple purchases that were of no clear value to the union.
 The employee was fired, Mr. Alvarez said, but he would not identify her. No charges have yet been filed against the employee or Mr. Caffey, who said through his lawyer he would not respond to questions about the incident. 
 In a series of interviews conducted over the last several weeks, labor leaders and others who have dealt with Mr. Caffey suggested that the scandal had cut short the career of one of the region's most influential and most enigmatic labor leaders.
 Their recollections and opinions painted a picture of a man who largely kept his own counsel as he worked his way up through the ranks of the Seafarers International Union of North America and through leadership positions in the A.F.L.-C.I.O., never quite losing the brusqueness and sometimes crusty style that accompanied, and perhaps facilitated, his rise from the waterfront. 
 ''Jack would tell it like it is, to the point that some found him offensive,'' said Thomas F. Germano, the director of the Center for Labor Management Relations & Dispute Resolution at Dowling College and a longtime colleague of Mr. Caffey. ''Jack wouldn't spare your feelings. He definitely had his rough edges.''
 Former colleagues, movement supporters and others who dealt with him said that Mr. Caffey maintained an independent streak, offering a chilly welcome at best to other labor leaders. That posture may have undermined his leadership, several labor leaders said, because the union's national leadership wanted the federation to serve as a Big Tent, attracting as many of the union's local members as possible. 
 Ninety-two union locals representing about 110,000 workers are dues-paying members of the Fed, Mr. Alvarez said. The other 140,000 workers on Long Island that the Fed claims it represents belong to the national union, but not the local council.
 Mr. Caffey's track record in recruiting locals did not escape the union's national leadership.
 ''The national A.F.L.-C.I.O has been doing efforts to reunify the labor movement on Long Island, including trying to work with unions that over the years had stepped back and not participated'' in the Fed, Mr. Alvarez said. ''We are making efforts to try to reinvolve them.''
 In the weeks following Mr. Caffey's suspension, few labor leaders have rushed to defend him publicly, and several spoke with open enthusiasm of the prospects for a change in leadership.
 ''I think it's going to be a golden opportunity to make us stronger,'' said Jack Kennedy, the president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, the largest affiliate in the Fed, with 60,000 members. 
 Describing the state of Long Island organized labor in recent years, Mr. Kennedy said, ''we were too fragmented before and too many egos were involved.'' But with new leadership in place, Mr. Kennedy said, ''I see the whole thing coming out stronger and better.''
 The turmoil at the Fed comes at a time when unions are struggling to reposition themselves to remain relevant in a changing economy. ''A big problem for organized labor is the fact that manufacturing is being reduced at a very rapid rate,'' said Murray Portnoy, a founder of Portnoy, Messenger, Pearl & Associates, a Syosset consulting firm that helps management in labor disputes.
 While much of labor's traditional organizing territory is shrinking on Long Island, the ranks of government employees are growing, but the Fed has made little progress in bringing them into the fold. By some accounts, feuds between the Fed's leadership and the leaders of locals representing government employees go back a generation or more. 
 Through the mid-70's, the Nassau and Suffolk locals of the New York State United Teachers union did belong to the Fed, said John DeGregorio, who served as the teachers' regional leader until his retirement last year, after nearly 40 years.
 The teachers dropped out around 1975, Mr. DeGregorio said, but he did not remember why. Over the years, he often encountered Mr. Caffey at labor functions, he said, but Mr. Caffey never suggested that the two locals patch up their differences. ''He never brought it up with me,'' Mr. DeGregorio said.
 Gary Dela Raba, the president of the Nassau Police Benevolent Association, reported a similar experience. ''I've been here as president since 1988, and we were never invited to join,'' he said.
 Mr. Caffey distanced himself from most of the alliances being formed on Long Island during the 1990's between organized labor and community, religious and left-leaning political groups, said Ms. Pannullo, the former Long Island Progressive Coalition leader who is now the executive director of the Suffolk County Community Council. 
 ''There were some progressive unions we worked closely with, but the Fed was not one of them,'' she said. ''The problem with the Fed was that it was a conservative body. At the other labor organizations, the leaders were with us.'' 
 Mr. Germano, the labor center director at Dowling, sought to defend Mr. Caffey's reputation. ''Jack raised the bar in the political arena,'' he said. ''He had very strong relationships with elected officials. When Jack Caffey called, they responded immediately. He had real influence. He instituted a Congressional night where every Long Island member of Congress would appear.'' 
 Mr. Germano said he was impressed with Mr. Caffey's political prowess, which signaled a radical reversal of the relationship between the Fed and the Congressional delegation in the 1990's. The situation ''was totally different from what came before him,'' Mr. Germano said.
 Leaders of several locals suggested that a new leader of the Fed, especially one with a more pronounced bent toward inclusiveness, might ultimately benefit Long Island labor. Nick LaMorte, the president of the Civil Service Employees Association on Long Island, attributed what he described as the Fed's fractiousness to poor communications.
 ''There are a lot of union members who don't even know what local they belong to,'' Mr. LaMorte said. ''Communication at the local level is probably the biggest problem unions have. But now we have the opportunity to be innovative and change the face of Long Island labor, and maybe even its structure. We can take it from a one-man show to a show of many faces and many people. People will now have an opportunity to belong to a larger and more inclusive federation.''
 Mr. Alvarez, the local's interim president, said he expected that the Fed would soon heal from the spending scandal. ''We will use the fact that there was this unfortunate situation to better align the organization with the needs of our member organizations,'' he said. ''The Fed has been very successful in terms of political activism. The five Congressional seats from Long Island have moved from the majority being either oppositional to labor, or weakly supportive, to being overwhelmingly pro-labor. The union is recognized as an effective lobbying force. I think we can build on that.''

 IN JUNE, Jack Caffey was suspended as president of the Federation of Labor. (Photo by Phil Marino for The New York Times)(pg. 1)

HEADLINE: In Sea Cliff, the Battle of the Tower

BYLINE: By NANCY H. TILGHMAN

 BODY:
SINCE January, Katie Seiden, a sculptor in Sea Cliff, has been peppering her village with petitions and appeals opposing its plan to build a 12-story cellphone tower disguised as a flagpole. 
 The Seidens and about 30 other Sea Cliff residents living near the proposed tower, on Altamont Street at the village public works department's yard, claim the tower would violate local zoning ordinances and possibly create health risks. They are asking the village to offer wireless carriers space on an existing 100-foot water tower nearby, or to wait until next year when the water tower is scheduled to be rebuilt and could be configured to allow up to six cellular carriers to install antennas.
 Mayor Irene Krieb and the village trustees argue that the proposed tower would produce rental income for the village, provide better reception than the water tower and, by accommodating all the wireless carriers now offering service in the area, prevent a profusion of smaller antennas from going up in the future. 
 ''We could ensure that it looked like a flagpole as opposed to an erector set,'' Dan Maddock, the village administrator, said of the proposed tower, ''and the residents would get substantial revenue from it, at least $100,000 a year. It's a win-win situation.'' 
 If the water tower is used instead, the revenue would flow to Acquarion, a Connecticut-based private company that owns the Sea Cliff Water Company. But Mr. Maddock said that whatever the resolution, some residents will be upset.
 Sea Cliff, described by another anti-tower resident, Herb Coston, as ''a town of Victorian houses, painters, old hippies and Range Rover Republicans,'' is only one of many local battlegrounds over cell towers, the building blocks of a network used by more than half of Long Islanders. Because federal law allows municipalities to control general placement, construction and modification of cellphone towers but does not allow them to ban towers outright, local disputes over cell towers can drag on for years. In Orient, negotiations between residents and local officials about whether to build a tower in their village have lasted almost 14 years.
 Most of the disputes boil down to which tradeoffs are acceptable and which aren't. Residents want better cell service, but to get it the wireless carriers have to build more towers. And when it comes to looking at a huge artificial tree or flagpole, many residents tend to favor solutions that provide lower-quality service, like attaching smaller antennas to church steeples, clock towers or buildings. 
 Low-capacity rooftop transmitters usually work well in urban areas and are more palatable to most residents. But in many suburban areas the best option is to build a free-standing tower. Residents tend to favor the shortest tower possible, but the lower the tower, the fewer carriers that can use it. Colocation, or the ganging of several carriers on one tower, consolidates the environmental impact and increases the rental income, which can be a substantial factor. For example, Anne Hopkins, president of the Orient Association, a civic group, said the local Congregational church gets roughly $3,000 a month for the antenna Sprint built inside its steeple. (The question of whether there will be a tower in Orient is still under discussion. The 120-foot proposed tower with four carriers colocated could provide as much as $72,000 a year.)
 All these issues are in play in Sea Cliff. Julia Cagney, a Bayville resident who tutors in Sea Cliff, said: ''I was one of the last people on the planet to buy a cellphone. When I got one I thought, 'Great, now it doesn't work.' But it wasn't that my cellphone didn't work, it was the reception was terrible. I started using it out of Sea Cliff and the area, and it worked fine. This whole area has terrible reception.'' 
 Jean Marie Stalzer, a real estate broker living in Sea Cliff, complains that cellphone reception on the North Shore is at best frustrating. ''I have 1,200 minutes a month,'' she said, ''but I can't use it inside my house or outside.'' Ms. Stalzer wants a cell tower built in Sea Cliff. 
 But many others do not want a 120-foot tower nearby. ''They say flagpole, but really it is a fiberglass stealth tower that would dwarf everybody in the neighborhood,'' Ms. Seiden said.
 The cellphone works on basic radio technology. When a cellphone call is made, its signal is usually picked up by a local antenna operated by the subscriber's company. If a caller moves out of range -- one to seven miles, depending on local terrain and traffic volume, a Verizon Wireless spokeswoman said -- the cellphone's signal is normally picked up by another antenna. But if too many trees or buildings are in the way, or if the antenna is overloaded with calls, the call won't go through, or will be lost. Although capacity varies according to tower height and location, typically one tower can accommodate between 100 and 250 calls at one time.
 Overloading increases as the number of wireless subscribers rises. Jo Bradshaw, chief executive of a Web site called wirelessadvisor.com, said there were nearly 1.5 million cellphone users in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, which have a combined population of 2.7 million. 
 Vince Cannuscio, former Southampton town supervisor and president of Beacon Wireless Management, a company based in Hampton Bays that develops cell sites on the Island, said seamless service becomes even more important as more and more people use wireless as their primary phones to replace traditional land-line phones. And Sgt. John Johnson, a spokesman for the Suffolk County Police Department, said that more than 50 percent of calls to its 911 operators come from cellphones.
 Steve Powell, a Verizon Wireless technician who drives around the Island in a test vehicle looking for dead spots, dropped calls and areas that need better signal strength, said, ''If there are dead spots, I'm willing to bet there was an attempt at coverage in those areas.'' 
 Deep pockets may be why some of the neighboring towns have avoided towers.
 ''I think influential resistance has thwarted the cell tower incursion,'' Mr. Coston said.
 Mike Kulak, a contractor engineer who asked that the wireless companies he works for not be named because he wants to continue getting jobs from them, cited economics as the main reason cellphone reception may be weak in certain areas. ''It's simple: the richer your neighborhood, the poorer your reception is going to be,'' he said. ''The poorer your neighborhood -- look at Queens. Great reception. The politics of cell towers has nothing to do with technology or the laws of physics.''

HEADLINE: Downtown Milford Is Now Hip In Months With or Without an R

BYLINE: By JEFF HOLTZ

 BODY:
BOATS from a nearby island docking in the harbor. Groups of 20-and 30-somethings making the rounds of crowded patio bars. The sounds of a live Mariachi band coming from an open-air restaurant. Tourists browsing local shops and trendy boutiques and relaxing in hip coffee shops.
 While it may sound like a resort town in Mexico, the Caribbean or some other exotic spot, it is actually downtown Milford. 
 Through what city officials and business leaders said was a well-executed plan, downtown Milford has turned itself from a rather nondescript cluster of stores into a destination for nightlife, a place for a weekend getaway and desirable place to live.
 According to the city's chamber of commerce, there are now 20 restaurants, 35 retail shops and 59 of what it considered service businesses downtown, many having moved in within the last five years.
 And the Milford police estimated average nightly crowds downtown this summer on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays with good weather have been around 3,000.
 The Stonebridge Restaurant on Daniel Street was at the heart of the emergence. The owner, Richard Conine, whose father started the Milford Seafood fish market at the same location in the 1940's, said his annual sales have gone from $700,000 in 1997 to $3 million. He said most of it came from his outdoor bar, which often draws 1,200 people on weekend nights in the summer.
 ''A lot of people on the Connecticut shore were always going over to Port Jefferson on Long Island for fun and excitement,'' said Mr. Conine, who will soon be opening a nightclub across from the restaurant. ''I've always viewed Milford Harbor as a possible Port Jeff. And I' think we've passed what they've done.''
 And it appears many Long Islanders have agreed. According to Dick Hosking, the director of operations at Lisman's Landing, a city-owned marina with 40 slips, which opened nine years ago on the former site of a sewer treatment plant in the downtown's harbor, 50 percent of the boats docking there had come from Long Island. He said the rest had come from Connecticut, New York, New Jersey and even Philadelphia.
 Mr. Hosking said the marina, which allows only hourly and overnight docking, averaged 2,000 guests in 2003 and was 20 percent ahead of that pace this year. He said weekends were ''packed'' and required reservations. He said the weekend of the annual oyster festival was usually sold out by January.
 ''Every year it gets bigger and bigger,'' Mr. Hosking said. ''People like the fact that we're so close to town. There's probably nine restaurants within two blocks of here.''
 And people who said they were driving to downtown also said they enjoyed being able to walk from place to place.
 Alberto Gonzales, an engineer from East Haven, said he and his friends drove there regularly on Friday nights.
 ''We usually go to about five places,'' he said, while relaxing at an outdoor table at Stonebridge Restaurant. ''It's a big plus to not have to worry about driving around. The green is nice. There's a lot of beautiful women. What more could you ask for?''
 Robert Smith Jr., the president of the Smith Craft Real Estate Corporation, which owns 11 commercial and residential properties downtown and has been the neighborhood's main developer, said the price of rental space has nearly tripled there in the last few years and the price of real estate has doubled.
 Mr. Smith credited city leaders, who consulted with Yale University's School of Urban Design on the redevelopment, for spurring the growth by allowing more residential properties to be built downtown, which increased business for merchants.
 ''We had a definite vision,'' he said. ''However, we needed zoning regulations to be amended or changed. They were open to our ideas, many of which didn't conform to the regulations at the time.''
 According to Robert B. Gregory, the city's economic development director, there are about 2,000 people living downtown. He said condominiums were being built that were expected to sell for around $500,000.
 Retailers have begun to notice downtown Milford, too. Mr. Smith said he is negotiating with a national clothier for a downtown location. In April, Pink By the Harbor, a boutique that specializes in the Lily Pulitzer line, opened across from the marina.
 ''Lily Pulitzer is mostly coastal-themed, so this is a perfect location,'' said Stacie Liao, the owner. ''Business has been great. It's been even better than I expected.''
 The development has not come without some minor problem. Some visitors said parking was difficult at times. Officer Vaughn Dumas, a spokesman for the Milford Police, said there have been a small number of fights and drug arrests in parking lots.
 Mayor James L. Richetelli Jr. said the city has formed a '''parking task force'' to address the downtown situation. He said the city planned to improve signs to better direct people to parking areas they don't know about.
 ''We know we need to improve the flow of traffic and improve pedestrian safety,'' he said. ''We want people to come down, park their cars, dock their boats and be able to walk around.''
 Richard Platt, official historian for the city, said the redevelopment has revived downtown.
 ''There are new restaurants doing well, and older businesses like Harrison's Hardware, which has been there for 100 years, is doing well,'' Mr. Platt said. ''About the only negative was the demise of the Capitol Theater, which was torn down years ago and which was located on what is now the parking lot for Stonebridge Restaurant.'' 
 Win Smith, a Republican state senator representing Milford, had praise for the redevelopment. However, he said there is some concern about new buildings ''pressing into some historically significant neighborhoods'' in the downtown area. ''With more development, the pressure is going to increase,'' said Mr. Smith, who is looking into the issue as a member of the city's Historic District Study Commission.
 ''There's a little bit of tension that we're trying to absolve in a positive way.''
 Over all, city officials are extremely pleased and looking toward the future. Mr. Gregory said a small river walk along the Wepawaug River, which includes waterfalls and runs through downtown and into the harbor, was being considered. And a New Year's eve celebration with family events, a parade and fireworks will take place downtown this year.
 And it hasn't just been out of towners taking advantage of downtown Milford's transformation. Natives said they were, too.
 ''Milford has changed,'' Stephanie Ancillai, 27, who was in between jobs in public relations, said on the outdoor patio at Amberjacks restaurant on a recent Friday night. ''It's a lot different than the Milford I grew up in. I want to hang out here, more than I did when I was 16 or 17 and couldn't wait to leave.''

HEADLINE: France Takes Reins of NATO Force in Kosovo at Trying Time

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH

DATELINE: PRISTINA, Kosovo, Sept. 1 

 BODY:
France took command of NATO peacekeeping operations in this Serbian province on Wednesday. The move puts French generals in charge of NATO's two major current operations, here in Kosovo and in Afghanistan, where a French officer took command of NATO forces in August.
 The voluntary commands are seen by American and European diplomats as a sort of antidote for France's poisoning of American-led NATO ambitions in Iraq, where France has only reluctantly agreed to allow a tiny NATO training program. France has refused to participate in the program. 
 ''It's impressive to NATO allies that France has stepped forward to lead these two missions,'' said a British official in Brussels, where NATO has headquarters. The official, who insisted on anonymity, called the French move a ''sea change'' in the country's recent attitude toward the trans-Atlantic alliance. France has sought to block NATO from engaging in a broader mission in Iraq.
 France's command is beginning at a difficult time for Kosovo, shortly before the province holds parliamentary elections and just six months after the delicate peace imposed by NATO after the 1998-99 war was punctured by widespread violence between Serbs and ethnic Albanians. The arson and shootings left 19 people dead and forced more than 4,000 people from their homes.
 ''We're entering a period of maximum risk,'' said France's defense minister, Michele Alliot-Marie, who attended the transfer ceremony on Wednesday from German to French command. ''The situation is calm but extremely fragile.''
 Human rights organizations criticized NATO peacekeepers for failing to stem the violence, in many cases having remained in their compounds while rioting took place outside. The worst of the violence took place in the zone under French control.
 ''U.S. forces, Swedes and Norwegians were in the streets but some countries' troops didn't leave their barracks,'' a senior NATO official in Brussels, who would not be identified by name, complained Wednesday.
 Adm. Gregory Johnson, commander of NATO forces in Southern Europe, praised the departing German commander, Gen. Holger Kammerhoff, at the transfer ceremony, but not before delivering a general rebuke to the peacekeepers for failing to prevent the violence in March.
 ''The standards of those days don't meet the expectations of the North Atlantic alliance,'' Admiral Johnson said, adding that the response to the rioting was complicated by ''national caveats'' among the multinational peacekeeping force -- a reference to varying rules of engagement between participating countries that prevented some troops from reacting promptly and effectively.
 General Kammerhoff said in his departure speech, ''I've enjoyed every day that I was here, except, perhaps, those three days in March.'' 
 Maj. Gen. Yves de Kermabon of France, who has served two previous tours in Kosovo, took over the command for a one-year term. NATO members volunteer for command of the operation on a rotating basis.
 The transfer took place at the peacekeepers' headquarters, surrounded by concertina wire and wood-frame buildings beyond which lie the red-tile roofs of Film City, named for its former ambition to be Yugoslavia's Hollywood. The peacekeepers' presence drives the local economy. On the road to the headquarters, My Thai Massage, promising ''relaxation,'' is thriving.
 After five years of United Nations administration, Kosovo still has displaced families, chronic unemployment and a crippled economy dominated in many areas by organized crime. Its ultimate status, either as a province of Serbia or independent state, has yet to be resolved.
 ''Now there's an effort to speed up the political timetable for final status talks, which could take place in 2005,'' the NATO official said, adding that NATO has decided to keep its peacekeeping force at nearly 20,000.
 At the transfer ceremony, Kosovo's president, Ibrahim Rugova, said he was looking forward to the day that Kosovo could ''enjoy recognition of its independence and integration into the European Union and NATO'' -- goals that remain a distant dream.
