HEADLINE: Emerging From The Mist

BYLINE: By HERBERT BUCHSBAUM. 
HERBERT BUCHSBAUM is a writer and photographer based in Mexico City.

 BODY:
THE taxi driver crosses himself as we enter the winding two-lane highway and start to rise out of San Cristobal de las Casas into the clouds. We look out the windows in silence, the first pangs of post-vacation blues creeping in.
 It's one of those mythical, mystical San Cristobal afternoons -- the sun is bright enough to make you squint, but earthbound clouds reduce visibility to 20 feet. Roadside tableaus pop up out of nowhere and disappear just as quickly: A Tzotzil Indian girl watches a flock of black sheep nibble the roadside vegetation, a pair of bare baby feet poking out of the green-and-indigo rebozo slung across her back. A band appears, two marimbas and a gleaming red electric guitar, atop a flatbed trailer in a strip mall parking lot, while a row of Indian men in pink-and-blue floral tunics sit on the curb listening. 
 And now something else: a white-haired man with a bundle of blue orchids on his back, their green stems, a yard long, tied together with rope. Then he, too, disappears into the mist. 
 We speed away, but the images linger, leaving me with the essence of this place: its otherworldly beauty and enduring poverty, its ancient indigenous ways and modern anachronisms, its brilliant color and diffuse light.
 Today, San Cristobal, a city of about 100,000 in Mexico's southern highlands, is rising from a different sort of mist. Although the remote colonial capital has always drawn a certain kind of traveler -- mainly Pan-American backpackers and the anthropologically inclined -- a more conventional tourist trade was emerging when, on Jan. 1, 1994, the city made international news. A thousand or so Indians armed with machetes, farm implements and battered carbines, their faces hidden in black ski masks, marched down from the surrounding hills and took the city, launching an audacious uprising for Indian rights and the world's first major strike against economic globalization. Mexican troops drove the rebels out 10 days later, leaving an estimated 150 rebels and soldiers dead. 
 The city's new image as a combat zone drove a stake through the heart of regional tourism. Foreign governments, including the United States, warned their citizens to stay away. When my wife and I first visited in 1995, the city was devoid of all but the hardiest travelers.
 A decade later, tourism has rebounded to record levels. According to the latest official tally, the number of tourists visiting San Cristobal increased 37 percent between 2001 and 2003. When we returned in May, we found the historic center buzzing with a lively cafe scene, a thriving pedestrian shopping and dining strip and a number of elegant hotels in colonial mansions. The Zapatista rebels had become less an armed menace than a radical-chic tourist attraction, but prices remained near conflict-era lows. 
 The city still attracts its share of backpackers, bohemians and revolutionary wannabes, but increasing numbers of older, affluent travelers also come to take in the city's colonial architecture, rugged mountain setting and traditional Maya culture.
 Tourism officials expect these trends to continue, if not accelerate. A new highway to the regional airport at Tuxtla Guttierez, scheduled to open in December, will cut travel time to the city by half, to less than an hour. A large mall and chain motels are rising on the outskirts. And a Domino's pizza (although discreetly signed) now fronts the 16th century zocalo, so far the only American franchise visible in the city center.
 While San Cristobal will soon make a larger mark for itself on the tourist map, the town is in no danger of losing the feel of a Spanish colonial outpost deep in the heart of Indian territory. Although the city is officially 35 percent indigenous, that figure is misleadingly low. The surrounding mountains are dotted with dozens of Indian villages for which San Cristobal is the main trading center. So across the graceful colonial squares and arcades, under the cast-iron balconies and ocher-and-rust-colored churches, passes a constant pageant of women in intricately woven scarlet and indigo shawls, men in ribboned sombreros and floral tunics and girls in blue satin blouses and long black braids tied together in back with colored yarn.
 Each costume signifies the wearer's village, and it is in the villages that Maya life continues on its own terms, on its own turf. On our first visit, we took a day trip to two Tzotzil Maya villages, Zinacantan and San Juan Chamula. In Zinacantan, we watched women weaving on backstrap looms, the centuries-old technique that produces the region's rich textiles, with symbolic patterns drawn from Maya cosmology.
 But it was the church of San Juan Chamula that cracked a mind-boggling window into the spiritual side of this extraordinary culture. Ostensibly Catholic (although no ordained priest has been allowed to say Mass there since 1968), the dark, candlelit church is far closer to its animistic pagan roots than to anything ever conjured by Rome. Copal burned in pumice censers and knots of worshipers sat on a pine-needle-covered floor surrounded by sacramental objects -- eggs, pox (a homemade cane and pineapple liquor pronounced posh), a gutted sacrificial chicken or two and bottles of Coca-Cola. Curanderos, traditional healers, rub the eggs and chickens on the infirm to draw out illness. Coke produces burps, which are believed to expel evil spirits. 
 This year, with only a long weekend at our disposal, we had no time for out-of-town excursions. Having previously gotten a taste of the villages (which, we were assured by guides and other travelers, haven't changed since) and museums (Na Balom, in particular, has a small but amazing collection of historical photographs and artifacts of Maya life), we sought nothing more culturally edifying than a relaxing getaway. We wanted only to take leisurely strolls along narrow flagstone streets, sip cappuccino in outdoor cafes and eat in good restaurants, and do all that in a town that still feels more like real Mexico than suburban Santa Fe.
 We checked into the Posada el Paraiso, a small hotel operated by a Swiss-Mexican couple in a restored colonial town house on a quiet street in the city center. Our room, with exposed wooden beams and washed sienna walls, was simple and tasteful. The bathroom of rough gray stone and Talavera tile reflected a seamless melding of modern European and traditional Mexican styles. 
 We immediately headed for the two central plazas, half a block from our hotel. San Cristobal is a great walking city. Its gentle hills, compact center, grid layout and cool climate make getting around on foot an easy pleasure, rewarding the visitor with startling new mountain vistas around each corner. We began at the center, the leafy Plaza 31 de Marzo, the town's zocalo, or central square.
 A two-story Art Nouveau gazebo, which houses a pleasant cafe, anchors the plaza, its 19th-century ironwork painted Crayola green to match the surrounding cast-iron benches and trident-shaped street lamps. Its yellow and white masonry picks up the birthday cake colors of the 1885 Palacio Municipal to the west, which served briefly as the Chiapas state capitol until Mexico City authorities yanked the designation to punish the San Cristobal elite for their royalist ways. To the north lies the city's impressive ocher-and-red cathedral, begun in the 16th century.
 If our wandering had any objective, it was to make it eventually to the two Indian markets on the north side of town. We walked north on 20 de Noviembre, which, since our last visit, had been converted into a pedestrian mall lined with restaurants, cafes and shops, until we reached the 16th-century Templo de Santo Domingo, whose Baroque facade glows pink in the late-afternoon sun. 
 Surrounding the church and an adjoining former monastery is an informal market where Indian artisans from nearby villages sell their wares directly to tourists. The steps and plazas are piled high with woven belts, blankets and tablecloths, embroidered peasant blouses, leather belts and briefcases, and handmade jewelry. The quality ranges from cheap to masterful, and prices, after the requisite bargaining, from cheap to reasonable.
 On our first trip, we bought a finely embroidered tablecloth and a few little effigies of the popular Zapatista leader Subcomandante Marcos, wearing his trademark ski mask and brandishing a crudely carved wooden rifle. This time we couldn't resist some colorful stuffed toy serpents, scrunchies made of Guatemalan-style fabric for my teenage daughter and a few embroidered pillowcases.
 Around the corner from the monastery's main entrance and easy to miss, lies a small gallery called Sna Jolobil (Weavers' House in Tzotzil), an indigenous weavers' cooperative where both prices and quality are significantly higher, worth a look even if you're not buying.
 Two blocks north and east, the Mercado Central functions as the city farmers' market, where Indians come from their villages to sell their produce. Tourists rarely venture in, hotel dwellers having no practical reason to food shop, but they're missing one of the best shows in town.
 Even among the poorest farmers here, presentation is paramount. Figs, plums, guayabas, limes and tejocotes are arranged in perfect pyramids in plastic buckets. Mounds of mangoes and piles of green beans fill wide straw baskets. Chilies, dried and fresh, crown conical brown ceramic bowls. Buckets of long-stemmed calla lilies, birds of paradise and roses line the shelves of flower stalls. The chickens are live, their feet tied together with plastic twine so a shopper can simply slip her arm between the legs and carry the occasionally flapping bird upside-down next to her shopping bag.
 We spent nothing there except time, and enjoyed every minute.
 Our only disappointment was on the culinary front. The first night, we tried a highly recommended French-Mexican restaurant, which was disastrous. Our second night, risking fusion cuisine again, we dined at our hotel's Swiss-Mexican restaurant, L'Eden, out of sheer convenience, and were pleasantly surprised. The ingredients were fresh and the binational combinations innovative. The tomato-basil sopa Azteca, for instance, was a delicious spin off the classic Mexican soup, with submerged avocado slices and crisp tortilla chips, served au gratin. After dinner we strolled around the zocalo, not once feeling uncomfortable or concerned for our well-being. 
 The only time we did fear for our safety was on the drive in from Tuxtla. The shuttles to San Cristobal are often piloted by young drivers who, despite the plastic Virgins dangling from the rearview mirror, or perhaps because of them, display little concern for their own mortality, much less their passengers'. As we careered along mountain roads, tires screeching to keep their grip on hairpin turns, our driver treated us to a particularly profane American rap tune, played at high volume and on repeat. As the speakers blared obscenities and the van sailed nonchalantly across the solid yellow line, I glanced at our fellow passengers, all Indians, staring ahead impassively. How do they do that, I wondered.
 We whipped around another curve, our bumper nearly scraping a stubby guardrail, beyond which the land dropped away some 1,500 feet. I considered the possibility that I might die flying into oblivion, accompanied by the jackhammer soundtrack of a potty-mouthed rapper.
 The new highway, when completed, will smooth out some of the curves and, if not eliminate the risks or the rap, at least halve your exposure to them. Until then, however, we improved our odds at shuttle roulette by choosing a private taxi with an older driver for the return trip. As we left the city, he crossed himself and we soared into the clouds.

Up in Chiapas
 Traveling to San Cristobal from the United States usually means flying to Mexico City, catching a Mexicana flight, (800) 531-7921, www.mexicana.com, to Tuxtla-Guttierez, the state capital, then taking a taxi ($47, at 11.5 pesos to the dollar) or collectivo (shared taxi, $16 a person). San Cristobal is considered safe. Hiking between Indian villages should not be tried alone or at night; some tourists have been robbed.

Where to Stay
 These hotels, in restored colonial buildings and centrally located, have private baths. Prices include tax.
 Posada el Paraiso, 5 de Febrero 19, (52-967) 678-0085, or visit www.hotelposadaparaiso.com, has 14 rooms that open onto a quiet street or courtyard and have phones but no TV. Doubles are $40.
 Hotel Flamboyant, 1 de Marzo 15, (52-967) 678-0045, from elsewhere in Mexico (01-800) 280-0500, has 82 rooms with cable TV and Talavera tile bathrooms. Doubles, $75.
 Casa Mexicana, 28 de Agosto 1, (52-967) 678-0698, or visit www.hotelcasamexicana.com, has a lush courtyard, folk-art decor, spa and an elegant restaurant. Doubles, $73.

Where to Eat and Drink
 Restaurant L'Eden, 5 de Febrero 19 (Posada el Paraiso hotel), (52-967) 678-0085, serves good Swiss-Mexican cuisine and generous steaks. Dinner for two $35, including its noted margaritas.
 Madre Tierra, Insurgentes 19, is a vegetarian restaurant with courtyard seating. Wonderful breakfasts, $7 for two, include excellent coffee, fresh tropical fruit and whole wheat pancakes with yogurt and honey. Also serves lunch and dinner, live music at night. 
 La Casa del Pan, Dr. Navarro 10, (52-967) 678-5895, also offers artfully prepared breakfasts, $11 for two, that include homemade breads, locally grown organic coffee and huevos a la Mexicana. Lunch and dinner, live music at night.

Maya Village Visits
 Several organizations offer four- to five-hour English-language tours by minivan to the Maya villages of San Juan Chamula and Zinacantan. Na Balom, the museum and guest house, Guerrero 33, (52-967) 678-1418, has tours leaving at 10 a.m. daily ($14). An independent guide, Mercedes Hernandez Gomez, leaves from the gazebo in Plaza 31 de Marzo daily at 9 a.m.; look for her multicolored golf umbrella ($10). Alex Aranda and Raul Garcia, (52-967) 678-3741, leave from the huge cross in front of the cathedral at 9:30 a.m. daily ($11). No reservations required. HERBERT BUCHSBAUM

HEADLINE: Does RAND Walk the Talk on Labor Policy?

BYLINE: By KAREN DONOVAN

 BODY:
SINCE the late 1980's, the RAND Corporation has done a fair amount of thinking for the Labor Department on topics like employee health benefits, pensions and sex discrimination, and whether giving patients the right to sue their managed-care plans for denying coverage would result in ''a flood of litigation.'' (It concluded that the results would be less than a deluge.)
 This year, RAND also published ''The 21st Century at Work,'' a sweeping study of how population changes, technology and globalization will affect the work force. Among its conclusions was that the loss of lifetime jobs and the shift toward self-employment ''call attention to the need for benefits that are portable across jobs.''
 But these weighty analyses have not been RAND's only contacts with the Labor Department, or with controversies over employee relations. RAND now faces a sex-discrimination class action filed by a group of women on its research staff, and three years ago it paid almost $200,000 to settle a government claim that it was violating the federal law that governs health and pension benefits. 
 In 1998, RAND settled Labor Department claims that its affirmative action plan, which federal contractors are required to maintain, was inadequate. The department found 12 violations that RAND agreed to fix -- without admitting or denying liability -- including the failure to keep the data needed to analyze the number and positions of the women or members of minorities it had hired. RAND agreed to compile the data and do the required analysis.
 Despite these problems with federal labor laws, RAND continues to get the bulk of its contracts from Washington -- more than $100 million last year.
 That may sound surprising. But RAND is not unique among government contractors in continuing to do business with the government after being found in violation of labor law.
 RAND, like all federal contractors, is subject to an executive order, dating to the Johnson administration, requiring it to create and put into effect an affirmative-action plan. The Labor Department, however, monitors just 8 percent of the companies it hires, according to the Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs, the arm of the Labor Department that conducts these investigations, mostly by asking contractors to mail in a copy of their plans.
 The ultimate punishment, debarment from working for federal agencies, has never been invoked against a major contractor.
 Boeing, one of the largest federal contractors, was the subject of a Labor Department investigation in 1998 over whether it was meeting its affirmative-action obligations. The issue arose in an on-site audit, and was settled in 1999 when Boeing offered $4.5 million in back pay and future pay adjustments to female and minority workers.
 But Boeing refused to turn over internal studies showing that it had been aware of pay disparities between men and women since at least 1994, saying the studies were subject to attorney-client privilege. It was later forced to turn over those studies in a class-action lawsuit, which it settled in July by agreeing to pay the class members -- as many as 29,000 current and former employees -- up to $72.5 million.
 To some people, the pay studies suggested that the problems at Boeing might have been deeper than the Labor Department realized when it settled with the company. But the lawyer for the Boeing plaintiffs, Joseph Sellers, said the Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs had never contacted him to review the information. 
 ''I think it underscores the importance of private enforcement,'' Mr. Sellers said, referring to the pursuit of a class-action suit.
 RAND traces its origins to 1945, when the Pentagon -- then the headquarters of the War Department -- concluded from its experience in World War II that independent research was vital. Project RAND, which stands for ''research and development,'' was set up under an Air Force contract with the Douglas Aircraft Company.
 It now splits its research between military and domestic policy topics, but for most of its history, RAND was devoted to military and national security issues. Several plaintiffs in the lawsuit said men were favored on what they called the ''military side of the house.''
 The suit, covering a period from 1995 to 1998, contends that job assignments, pay decisions, training and mentoring at RAND were all ''highly subjective'' and discriminated against women. Problems in mentoring were especially important, the plaintiffs say, because mentoring was crucial to getting high-profile research projects and moving up the corporate ladder.
 When Jeanne Jarvaise, one of the lead plaintiffs in the sex-discrimination suit, complained to her boss, Dr. David S.C. Chu, the director of research at RAND's office in Washington, about her difficulties in finding a mentor, she said, he told her that ''finding a mentor is like having a romance: it just happens.'' At a deposition in February 1998, Dr. Chu, now an under secretary of defense in the Bush administration, testified that he could not recollect saying anything to that effect.
 Ms. Jarvaise also complained to Dr. Chu that a male colleague undermined her by shutting her out of meetings with a client at the Defense Department when discussing their work on a project she had initiated. In the deposition, Dr. Chu testified that he did not think Ms. Jarvaise's concern was valid ''because association with individuals of your choice is still a right in this country.''
 RAND's defense counsel, Karen Kubin, said she believed that the only relevant issue in the case was whether the women in the class received unequal pay for equal work, and that lack of mentoring and getting shut out of meetings were ''irrelevant.'' 
 But Michael Lieder, the plaintiffs' lawyer, said these factors were ''all likely to have an impact on pay.''
 The case may come down to statistical evidence, filed with the court, on pay differences between men and women -- numbers that RAND, like most companies in its position, would prefer to keep away from the public. In July, Morgan Stanley paid $54 million to settle sex-discrimination claims on the eve of a trial, avoiding the prospect of evidence on pay becoming public. Boeing was forced to disclose internal pay studies to the plaintiffs suing it, but still insisted that the numbers not be made public.
 ''These companies are very eager to keep whatever shortcomings they have confidential,'' said Mr. Sellers, who represents the Boeing women. ''It's one thing to have this stuff subject to discovery; it's another thing to make them public.''
 Ms. Kubin, RAND's lawyer, has been aggressive in protecting pay statistics. At a hearing in January, she accused the plaintiffs' lawyers of violating a judge's order on confidentiality when they sent out a letter to the class members -- their own clients -- that referred to the company's numbers. 
 In 2002, Judge Richard W. Roberts of the Federal District Court in Washington agreed to approve a class action for 373 women who worked at RAND from 1995 to 1998, saying that the plaintiffs had used statistical evidence to establish a ''systemwide practice'' of paying women less than men.
 In a 1998 brief -- filed under seal, but obtained before plaintiffs' lawyers removed it from a Web site about the case -- the plaintiffs called women researchers ''shockingly underpaid'' in the 1990's. Their statistician, after examining RAND pay scales from 1992 to 1997, found that women researchers were paid, on average, $22,488 less than male counterparts in 1992. The gap narrowed to $21,408 by 1997 -- but men were still paid 33 percent more, on average.
 The statistician concluded that the pay disparities had been systemic even when considering factors like education and seniority. As of 1997, he said, the difference in annual pay attributed solely to being a woman was $5,907. 
 BUT RAND asserts that pay differences between men and women can be explained by differences in work experience. Ms. Kubin said that overlooking experience is ''the oldest mistake in the book.'' Since Judge Roberts approved the class action, the plaintiffs have hired a labor economist who they say will be better able to deal with the issue of what sorts of experience employees had.
 Federal contractors are not required to tell the government when they are sued on allegations of discrimination, and RAND has not formally notified Washington. ''It's a civil lawsuit,'' Ms. Kubin said, ''and they are unproven allegations.'' (Allison Elder, a RAND staffing manager, was similarly dismissive of the company's 1998 run-in with the Labor Department over affirmative action. She called that case a ''routine audit'' that found only ''technical record-keeping and reporting deficiencies.'' She added that the government did not find fault with RAND's treatment of its employees.)
 Although Labor Department investigators asserted labor law violations against the company and settled the claims in 2001, the department continues to contract with RAND. A department spokesman -- the Labor Department does not allow its spokesmen and spokeswomen to be identified by name -- said that breaking the rules did not necessarily disqualify a contractor.
 ''If someone gets a speeding ticket,'' he said, ''it doesn't mean they can't ever drive again.''


CORRECTION-DATE: October 10, 2004

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 5 about the RAND Corporation's labor policies referred imprecisely to a judicial finding in a sex discrimination lawsuit against the company. Judge Richard W. Roberts of the Federal District Court in Washington ruled in 2002 that the plaintiffs' statistical evidence had satisfied one prerequisite for the class action to proceed; he did not rule on the substance of their complaint, which, as the article said, is still waiting to be adjudicated. This correction was delayed for discussions with RAND about several aspects of the article.

HEADLINE: U.S. Low-Fare Airlines Branch Out Abroad

BYLINE: By MICHELINE MAYNARD

 BODY:
NOT long ago, traveling to winter vacation spots like the Bahamas and Mexico meant paying top prices on major airlines. Now, low-fare airlines are jumping in with new international service, hoping to steal customers from more established rivals just as they have in the United States.
 JetBlue Airways and Song, the low-fare wing of Delta Air Lines, plan to start flights to the Bahamas this fall. Another low-fare carrier, Ted, has gained official approval to fly to Mexico, and will begin service in December. 
 JetBlue, Song and Ted join other low-fare players such as Frontier Airlines, America West, Spirit Airlines and ATA Airlines, which already fly outside the United States. And many of these airlines are looking at expanding service beyond Caribbean and Central America -- to Canada and even to Europe.
 The reasons behind the low-fare airlines' rush outside the United States is twofold. First, the carriers want routes to destinations popular with Americans.
 Second, they sense a demand in other countries for cheaper flights to the United States, particularly in Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic where families often travel back and forth. 
 Among the likely results will be lower fares and expanded choices for travelers. ''The deals are going to get very good for consumers,'' said Robert W. Mann Jr., an airline industry consultant based in Port Washington, N.Y.
 JetBlue, which has been flying to Puerto Rico since 2002, has been rapidly expanding its international flights this year. In June, it began serving Santiago and Santo Domingo in the Dominican Republic.
 Starting Nov. 1, it plans to offer one flight a day from Kennedy Airport in New York to Nassau in the Bahamas. ''It's a place where people want to go,'' said David F. Ulmer, JetBlue's vice president for planning. ''At our prices, we hope there will be a lot of repeat visiting.''
 JetBlue has announced introductory fares of $99 to $249 each way, depending on flight times and departure day. And if there is enough demand, JetBlue will consider adding flights to Nassau from Boston and Washington, too, Mr. Ulmer said. A check of random dates in September and October on www.itasoftware.com and American Airlines' Web site yielded round-trip fares of about $320 to $390 for major carriers. 
 Song is already taking reservations for direct daily service between New York and Nassau, which begins Dec. 1. Song's service is in addition to the Delta flights, but those require a change of planes.
 On its Web site, Song is offering round-trip fares, purchased in advance, from New York to Nassau for $336. A similar flight on Delta listed at $815 round trip, with a connection through Atlanta.
 Competition is heating up among low-fare carriers for flights to Mexico. On Aug. 30, the federal government granted permission for Ted, a subsidiary of United, to operate flights from Denver to Mexico, a route already flown by Frontier.
 Ted plans to fly from Denver to Puerto Vallarta and Cancun, seasonally from December through April, beginning Dec. 16. Ted's Web site lists a round trip fare of $632 for the route. United has also been granted approval to start Ted service between San Francisco and Puerto Vallarta, beginning Dec. 16. 
 It would compete with another low-fare carrier, ATA, which already flies from Denver to Mexico and also serves Cancun from San Francisco.
 JetBlue is eager to fly to Cancun, too, said Mr. Ulmer. It is also looking to expand its routes to Canada from New York. 
 That expansion most likely will wait until JetBlue takes delivery on the first of 100 business jets from the Brazilian aircraft maker Embraer, due next year. The Embraer planes will seat 100 passengers, twice as many as conventional regional jets, and have a range of 2,000 miles. JetBlue has options on 100 jets beyond those, and a long list of cities clamoring for the airline to start service.
 That list does not include overseas destinations. But ATA plans to serve Europe starting in mid-2005. The airline hasn't said what its destinations will be, but the flights will have both economy and business-class sections, which it offers in the United States.
 ATA is experienced flying overseas as a charter carrier. But it has also run into financial difficulties. In mid-August, it warned that it could encounter a cash crisis early next year, due to rising fuel costs and other expenses, and analysts think those problems could delay its overseas expansion efforts.
 On Aug. 23, US Airways announced that it would turn Fort Lauderdale into a mini-hub in February for its service to the Caribbean and Latin America. The move, which depends on concessions by its unions, is in response to the invasion of low-fare airlines on those lucrative vacation routes.

HEADLINE: Amnesia In the Garden

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD. 
E-mail: liberties@nytimes.com

 BODY:
The Manichaean Candidate sees the world only in terms of good and evil, black and white. 
 He scorns gray, nuance, complexity, context, changing circumstances and inconvenient facts. Real men make their own reality. 
 Trying to match John Kerry, who roused the base at his convention with a line bashing the House of Bush-House of Saud coziness, George W. Bush roused the base at his convention with a liberal-media-elite-bashing line. 
 Painting himself as the noble agent for ''the transformational power of liberty'' abroad, he said ''there have always been doubters'' when America uses its ''strength'' to ''advance freedom'': ''In 1946, 18 months after the fall of Berlin to Allied forces, a journalist in The New York Times wrote this: 'Germany is a land in an acute stage of economic, political and moral crisis. European capitals are frightened. In every military headquarters, one meets alarmed officials doing their utmost to deal with the consequences of the occupation policy that they admit has failed.' End quote. Maybe that same person's still around, writing editorials.''
 She isn't. Anne O'Hare McCormick, who died in 1954, was The Times's pioneering foreign affairs correspondent who covered the real Axis of Evil, interviewing Hitler, Stalin, Mussolini and Patton. She was hardly a left-wing radical or defeatist. In 1937, she became the first woman to win a Pulitzer Prize in journalism, and she was the first woman to be a member of The Times's editorial board.
 The president distorted the columnist's dispatch. The ''moral crisis'' and failure she described were in the British and French sectors. She reported that the Americans were doing better because of their policy to ''encourage initiative and develop self-government.'' She wanted the U.S. to commit more troops and stay the course -- not cut and run. 
 Mr. Bush Swift-boated her.
 The Manichaean Candidate's convention was a brazen bizarro masterpiece. The case to sack John Kerry featured the same shady tactics used to build the case to whack Saddam -- cherry-picked facts, selective claims and warped contexts. 
 W. took a page from Arnold Schwarzenegger's ''Total Recall,'' a futuristic movie about inserting fully formed memories into the minds of unsuspecting victims.
 The president and vice president ignored all the expert evidence now compiled indicating no link between 9/11 and Saddam, and no Saddam threat to U.S. security. After talking about ''the fanatics who killed some 3,000 of our fellow Americans,'' Dick Cheney boasted: ''In Iraq, we dealt with a gathering threat, and removed the regime of Saddam Hussein.''
 Though the convention mythologized Mr. Bush's bullhorn moment at ground zero, there was no mention of Osama, the fiend W. vowed to catch that day. The speakers did not acknowledge the brutal spiral in Afghanistan and Iraq, or the re-emergence of the Taliban, now finding sanctuary with our ally, Pakistan. 
 Mr. Cheney, king of hooey, bragged about a ''Taliban driven from power,'' even though just as the convention got under way, at least seven people, including two Americans, were killed by Taliban fighters in Kabul.
 W. stormed ahead with the discredited domino theory of democracy promoted by the neocons and Ahmad Chalabi -- ignoring the widening F.B.I. probe into alleged leaks from neocon central at the Pentagon to Mr. Chalabi, an accused Iranian spy, and to an Israeli lobby. ''Because we acted to defend our country, the murderous regimes of Saddam Hussein and the Taliban are history,'' the president said, adding that ''democracy is coming to the broader Middle East.''
 The $445 billion deficit? Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney erased it. In their inside-out universe, the economy is blossoming, there's money to pay for Mr. Bush's to-do list and No Child Left Behind is more than an empty slogan. 
 W. suddenly proclaimed himself a compassionate conservative again, even though extra-chromosome conservatives, as Lee Atwater called them, were in closed meetings calling for a culture war to curb the rights of women and gays. 
 Mr. Bush even tried to implant in our heads that he is the son of Reagan. He didn't give his dad a speaking slot, though the last two Democratic presidents spoke in Boston, and he spent more time in his speech lionizing Gip than Pop.
 Inside Madison Square Garden, W. kept insisting he'd made the world safer. Outside, the exploding world didn't seem safe at all.

LENGTH: 992 words

HEADLINE: It's Not Just About Jobs, but Where the Jobs Are

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
WITH Americans giving President Bush a big edge over Senator John Kerry on matters of national security, the hopes of the Kerry campaign rest on what they view as Mr. Bush's Achilles' heel: the loss of 900,000 jobs since Mr. Bush took office. 
 The situation seemed scarcely better after Friday's job report. Though the Labor Department report showed that the nation gained 144,000 jobs in August -- an increase Mr. Bush quickly trumpeted on the campaign trail -- Democrats noted that over all, the job loss is still the worst of any president since Herbert Hoover. Mr. Bush's supporters, however, have pointed out that nearly 1.7 million jobs have been created in the last year. But after increasing by nearly 300,000 jobs a month from March through May, the pace of the job creation has slowed sharply. During the economic expansion of the 1990's, job growth averaged 201,000 a month. 
 For Mr. Kerry and his campaign advisers, the jobs picture is more mixed than they care to acknowledge, and the nuances may help Mr. Bush. To borrow a phrase from a certain vice presidential candidate, what might help Mr. Bush is that there are two Americas -- one that has lost many jobs since he took office, and another that is doing just fine. 
 Among swing states, some, like Ohio and Michigan, have suffered large net job losses since January 2001, while others -- like Florida, Nevada and New Mexico -- have had large job gains. 
 ''The national job market is the sum of many regional job markets that have performed very differently,'' said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com, a consulting firm. ''Some areas have struggled and continue to struggle, while others have thrived, and all this can cut very differently for the presidential candidates in different states.''
 The two states where the electoral battle is particularly fierce -- Ohio and Florida -- are on different ends of the spectrum. Ohio has lost 230,000 jobs, or 4.1 percent of its jobs, since Mr. Bush took office, while Florida has gained 290,000 jobs, a 4 percent increase. While Mr. Bush won Ohio four years ago, the jobs picture has hurt his standing. 
 And Democrats, feeling they were cheated out of winning Florida in 2000, are campaigning feverishly to capture the state, but many Republicans say the strong economy could keep Florida in the Republican column. 
 ''The economy here is outstanding,'' said Mark Lang, chief executive of Workers Temporary Staffing, an Orlando company that provides labor to a booming construction industry. ''We've seen more jobs and higher pay for our workers. There's no doubt in my mind that the president will win Florida.''
 Hurricanes aside, Florida has received a lift from many quarters: the boom in defense spending, the influx of dollars from Latin America and the continuous arrival of old and not-so-old Americans and Canadians. This has produced a surge of jobs in construction, tourism, health care, education and retailing.
 Even though wage growth in Florida has been weak and even though job creation has not kept pace with population increases, Mr. Zandi, said, ''The president has a strong economic tailwind at his back in Florida.'' 
 Ohio is at the other pole. The state has lost 170,000 manufacturing jobs (a 17 percent drop since January 2001) -- including 22,000 in machinery manufacturing (a 20 percent loss) and 5,300 in steel (a 28 percent drop). 
 ''Our longest-serving governor, Jim Rhodes, always use to say there are three critical issues in the election: the first is jobs, the second is jobs and the third is jobs,'' said Andrew Doehrel, president of the Ohio Chamber of Commerce. ''Our jobs picture is not as strong as we would like.'' 
 Take Stark County, long the bellwether county in a bellwether state: as Stark County goes, so goes Ohio, and as Ohio goes, so goes the nation. In April, the Timken Company announced plans to close three ball-bearing factories and lay off 1,300 workers, while the Hoover Company, the vacuum cleaner maker, has laid off 500 workers. The announcements follow the layoff of 700 steelworkers at Republic Technologies and the loss of 200 jobs when the nation's lone rubber glove factory shut, moving production to India and Malaysia. In late July, Mr. Bush campaigned in Canton, the county seat, just three days after World Kitchen in nearby Massillon announced that it was closing its 200-employee bake ware factory in favor of importing bake ware from China. Since Mr. Bush took office, the Stark County area has lost 26 percent of its factory jobs, which are typically among the highest paying. 
 ''A lot of workers are upset about Bush,'' said Dan Sciury, president of the Greater Stark County A.F.L.-C.I.O. ''They see a lot of jobs going abroad, and he doesn't seem to be doing anything to stop the bleeding.''
 Still, as the campaign moves ahead, national security concerns could outweigh the job situation in enough crucial places to become the deciding factor in the race. 
 ''Bush is going into this election with people not feeling good about the economy and the job market,'' said Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center, who pointed to surveys showing that 66 percent of Americans say the economy is in poor or fair shape. ''But Bush has a lot of strength on the issue of terrorism, and that might offset the strong feelings people have about the economy.''
 Who wins in Florida and Ohio could hinge on some last-minute economic twists and turns. The recent drop in sales for Detroit's Big Three could cause layoffs at auto plants in Ohio and other Midwestern states in the next month. The calamitous hurricane season has run up huge costs, but it is also creating construction jobs by the thousands. 
 ''There's an ever-changing dynamic,'' said Mr. Doehrel of the chamber of commerce. ''If we continue to see the improvement that we've seen, it can be positive for the president. But if there's more of a downturn, it's going to make it tougher for him. No doubt about that.''

HEADLINE: Counting Down to the New Armageddon

BYLINE: By James Hoge. 
James Hoge is the editor of Foreign Affairs magazine.

 BODY:

NUCLEAR TERRORISM
The Ultimate Preventable Catastrophe.
By Graham Allison.
263 pp. Times Books/
Henry Holt & Company. $24.
 TERRORISTS are striving to acquire and then use nuclear weapons against the United States. Success, as defined by Osama bin Laden, would be four million dead Americans. Mounting evidence makes this much abundantly clear. Documents discovered in Afghanistan seem to reveal Al Qaeda's detailed knowledge of nuclear weaponry, while intelligence confirms the terrorists' attempts to acquire nuclear material on the black market. 
 In reaction, President George W. Bush and Senator John Kerry are giving pride of place to catastrophic terrorism in their foreign policy platforms. Both proclaim it the nation's No. 1 security challenge. Meanwhile, policy analysts have urgently recommended preventive measures in a flurry of reports, books, journal articles and Congressional testimony.
 Now the Harvard scholar Graham Allison is sounding his own warning in ''Nuclear Terrorism'' -- a well-written report for general readers on the threat and what it will take to reduce it. He addresses all the big questions: who could be planning an attack; how they might acquire and deliver the weapons; when they might launch the first assault. Allison touches on chemical and biological dangers, but he separates out the far more lethal nuclear threat for special attention. Nonnuclear radioactive (''dirty'') bombs and chemical or biological devices would kill in the thousands. A 10-kiloton nuclear bomb, delivered to Times Square by truck and then detonated, could kill up to one million New Yorkers. 
 Some experts think a terrorist attack with nuclear weapons is already unstoppable. Allison disagrees -- up to a point. He argues that prevention is still possible, and he gives the Bush administration some credit for several post-9/11 initiatives meant to tighten the security of nuclear weapons and material. However, he calls for far bolder measures, more money and forceful American leadership to improve what is at present rather lax international cooperation. His bottom line is blunt: anything less will make nuclear terrorism inevitable. 
 Allison blames both the White House and the Congress for falling short of meeting the challenge. To take one example, since 9/11 the rate of funding has hardly changed for the Nunn-Lugar program, which was established to destroy or secure Russia's enormous stockpile of fissile material and nuclear weapons. Much remains to be done. Of special concern is Russia's large supply of suitcase-size nuclear bombs, which terrorists could smuggle into the United States in cargo containers or as airline baggage. The safeguards on these weapons are loose at best. (In 1997, Russia acknowledged that 84 of some 132 such weapons were missing.) 
 At present, it will take 13 years, in Allison's estimation, to secure Russia's fissile material. Allison's position, adopted by the Kerry campaign, is to spend whatever dollars are necessary to complete the job in four years, though achieving this objective would also require elimination of Congressionally imposed impediments to Nunn-Lugar and overcoming Russian resistance to intrusion into their facilities.
 We face many vulnerabilities -- limited intelligence of the terrorists' plans; poorly protected ports, borders and nuclear power plants. But the most urgent danger is that terrorists could acquire the fissile material with which to construct a nuclear weapon in a relatively short period of time. Russia presents the greatest problem; 90 percent of all existing fissile material outside the United States is stored within the former Soviet Union. Still, it's not the only region we need to focus on. At least 32 countries possess weapons-grade fissile material.
 Allison would round up all fissile material and ban the creation of any more. This is a daunting task. Allison himself observes that there are some 200 locations around the world where nuclear weapons or fissile material could be acquired, and he pinpoints the most dangerous -- Russia because of its huge supplies, shaky safeguards and extensive corruption; Pakistan because of its indiscriminate spreading of nuclear know-how and equipment; North Korea because of its history of selling missile systems and its apparent nuclear development program; and lastly, the research reactors (some 20-odd) with significant quantities of bomb-grade uranium located in developing countries.
 Allison's other remedies -- like imposing intrusive nuclear power plant inspections and sanctioning violators -- may also prove difficult to implement in the real world of suspicious governments and corrupt officials. Because the United States is widely viewed with hostility these days, it may not be able to marshal the international support needed to shut down black markets or block the emergence of new nuclear weapons states. And then there is the question of money. Governments are reluctant to spend lavishly on prospective threats when tax-conscious citizens have not yet experienced any consequences. 
 As a champion of the idea that nuclear terrorism is preventable, Allison emphasizes the elements of an offense -- improved intelligence, tighter treaties, more transparency and intrusion. But a stronger homeland defense is also needed in case prevention by offense fails. And currently, homeland security is getting short shrift. For the 2005 budget, Congress has allotted $7.6 billion to improve the security of military bases but only $2.6 billion to protect the nation's vital infrastructure. Within the Department of Defense, $10 billion is spent annually on missile defense, compared with only a few billion on all other counterproliferation programs. 
 Homeland security becomes an even higher priority if one broadens one's thinking about the potential damage from nonnuclear weapons to include more than simply the number who would die. Allison is less concerned with biological and chemical weapons and so-called dirty bombs because they kill in the thousands, not millions. But these unconventional arms can still cause mass disruption; a few anthrax incidents, after all, virtually shut down the Congress. The release of pathogens in a public space, or a biological attack on the food supply system, or a dirty bomb set off in a seaport could have enormous economic consequences. Large-scale government efforts are needed to minimize the danger of such attacks.
 What makes the job of prevention all the more difficult is that the threat of nuclear terrorism is growing at the same time as the need for nuclear-generated electricity. Allison points out that all signatories to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty are permitted to enrich uranium and reprocess plutonium to make fuel for peaceful power reactors, provided they declare what they are doing and submit to periodic inspections. In other words, states can come to the brink of nuclear weapons capability without explicitly violating the treaty. Then, without penalty, they can withdraw from the treaty and turn enriched uranium or plutonium into bombs. 
 This is a loophole that both Iran and North Korea have sought to take advantage of. Allison and other experts argue that the United States should not discard the treaty but take the lead in fixing it. Their preferred solution is to distinguish ''fuel cycle'' states from ''user states.'' Those states where fuel-producing facilities already exist would provide enriched fuel to other states that wish to generate electricity from nuclear reactors. Coupling this with stiffer inspection provisions and penalties for withdrawal from the treaty would return the nonproliferation treaty to an important (if limited) role in countering proliferation. 
 Nuclear dangers come in several forms, those that might be mounted by states and those from terrorists that cannot be contained by treaties alone, no matter how strict. Allison covers all the potential eventualities but might have been clearer in setting priorities, since resources are limited. Rogue states, capable of launching nuclear-tipped missiles, may ultimately be a threat. But the evidence indicates that the danger currently lies elsewhere. The urgent threat is nuclear terrorism, and funds need to be freed up to fill the considerable holes remaining in our counterterrorism programs. 
 Allison's comprehensive but accessible treatment of this vital subject is a major contribution to public understanding. In turn, an informed public could spur the government to complete the counterterrorism agenda. Only then, as Allison argues, will nuclear terror against America prove preventable.
